title: How to Chop a Chicken

steps.headline: Remove the chicken from its packaging.
steps.description: Cut open the plastic packaging and take out the chicken. If the chicken is trussed with twine, plastic, or a rubber band, use a knife to cut any trussing materials and remove them from the chicken. Throw away all the packaging materials.Warning: The CDC does not recommend washing raw chicken, since doing so can spread dangerous bacteria. Take care when you remove the plastic wrap not to spill any juices that have pooled inside.

steps.headline: Put the chicken breast-up on a clean cutting surface.
steps.description: After you take the chicken out of its packaging, put it down on a sterile cutting board or a large plate. Put the chicken on its back with the breast facing up. Tip: To prevent other foods from getting contaminated, it’s a good idea to reserve 1 cutting board just for preparing raw chicken. You may wish to lay down some paper towels on your work area before you start to prevent any blood or juices from splashing on your counter.

steps.headline: Take out the neck and giblets if they’re present.
steps.description: Reach into the chicken’s body cavity and feel for a plastic or paper pouch, which will contain organs such as the liver, heart, and gizzard. If you find a giblet pouch, pull it out and set it aside. You may also find the neck inside the body cavity, either separately or bagged with the other giblets. If you wish, you can save the giblets to use in stock or other recipes. Otherwise, discard them with the packaging.

steps.headline: Trim off the fat around the body cavity.
steps.description: Sometimes a chicken will have large pieces of fat around the body cavity opening (near the tail) or the base of the neck. If you find any fat in these areas, use a sharp knife to cut it away. You can save the chicken fat if you like and use it for cooking. Add it to savory recipes where you would otherwise use butter for an extra rich flavor.

steps.headline: Cut off each wing where it connects to the breast.
steps.description: Grab one of the wings and wiggle it a little to help you find the joint that attaches it to the side of the breast. Use the end of a sharp kitchen knife to cut through the skin and joint and separate the wing from the body. Repeat the process on the other side. Tip: If the chicken is wet from thawing or sitting in the juices in the package, pat it down with a dry paper towel before you start cutting. This will make the skin less slippery and easier to cut. Pressing your thumb against the spot where the wing meets the body can make it easier to find the joint. If you pull up on the wing while you make the cut, the weight of the chicken will help make the separation easier. Ideally, you should use a sharp boning knife for this purpose. Always keep your fingers out of the way and use caution when working with sharp knives.

steps.headline: Slice the skin between the thigh and breast.
steps.description: Before you cut a leg, grab the leg and pull it away from the body. Cut the skin where the thigh attaches to the side of the breast. This will make it easier for you to see where the thigh joint is before you make your next cut.

steps.headline: Find the thigh joint and cut through it.
steps.description: Examine the cut you just made and find the joint where the thigh attaches to the body. You may find it helpful to wiggle the leg a bit to determine exactly where the joint is. Cut through the joint with your knife once you find it. Repeat this cut on the other thigh. You can also bend the thigh back to pop the joint out of its socket. This will make the joint even easier to find and cut. The joint will be located far down on the side of the chicken’s body, close to the back.

steps.headline: Make a cut at the joint between the thigh and the drumstick.
steps.description: If you like, you can now separate the thighs from the drumsticks. Lay the leg quarters skin-side-down and bend them a little to find the joint between the drumstick and thigh, then slice cleanly through the joint. You may notice a line of fat that runs across the leg right where the drumstick and thigh meet. Use this line as a guide when you are making your cut.

steps.headline: Remove the backbone with a sharp knife or kitchen shears.
steps.description: Next, pick up the chicken and hold it with the head-end down on the cutting surface. Look for the fat lines that run along the sides of the torso near the back and cut along those lines from tail to shoulder. Repeat this cut on both sides to remove the backbone. The fat line will start as a diagonal line that goes from the top of the body cavity opening and angles down toward the backbone over the thigh joints. You can use either a boning knife or a pair of kitchen shears for these cuts. To get the most out of your chicken, save the backbone and use it to make a delicious stock!

steps.headline: Cut through the breastbone to separate the breasts.
steps.description: Flip the breast over skin-down on the cutting board and make a small slit in the middle of the bone from the back. Then, flip the breast back over and push down on it with both hands to break the bone. Pull the breast halves apart slightly, then slice through the middle of the breast with your knife to separate them. Alternatively, you can cut directly through the breastbone from the back. You’ll need a lot of elbow grease to do this. Fold a kitchen towel and put it over the dull edge of your knife, then push down hard on the blade with your hands to force the knife through.
